settings.strbnr_desc: It started with a son and his father...

settings.advsr_desc: CuraLife’s medical advisory board chairman is Professor Itamar Raz, one of the top diabetologists in the world, the head of the Israel National Council of Diabetes and is the founder and head of the National Diabetes Prevention and Care Plan in Israel. Professor Raz has over 320 publications in peer-reviewed journals and headed the Diabetes Unit at Hadassah University Hospital from 2000-2015.

Dr. Sarah Brewer is a global expert in the field of Natural Sciences, with a MB from Cambridge University and a Master's degree from the University of Surrey. She has 30+ years of experience in prestigious hospitals and author of 60+ landmark books on health.

Dr. Sara Kaplan is a clinical dietitian and worldwide acclaimed diet expert. Dr. Kaplan heads the Department of Human Nutrition and Diet for a leading national private healthcare provider. Dr. Kaplan is the nutritional leader at CuraLife.

Joel has been a Partner at Mishcon de Reya since 2006. He advises and acts for entrepreneurs and company owners from a wide variety of business sectors, with a large part of his practice having an international aspect. He holds an LLB from Bar Ilan University and a Master's Degree in Law from London University. Joel is on the advisory board of CuraLife & two high-tech investment funds.

Dr. Choppe leads Cukierman & Co. Life Sciences and has been involved in more than 50 Medtech and biotech corporate finance transactions and advisory assignments. Laurent brings extensive international life sciences experience in managing multifunctional teams and setting up new businesses in pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, nutraceuticals, and direct-to-consumer markets. Dr. Choppe is a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine of the University Paris XII and earned an MBA from INSEAD (Fontainebleau, France).

Dr. Uri Eliyahu has a Ph.D in Medical Sciences specializing in Epidemiology. Dr. Eliyahu is a licensed pharmacist and holds a MSc in Physiology and Pharmacology. Dr Elyahu is a prestigious lecturer in top universities. Dr. Elyahu is the pharmacology lead at CuraLife.

settings.dia_titl: It started with a son and his father...
settings.dia_desc:
When my father was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, it transformed both our lives. I experienced first-hand the challenges my father faced maintaining a high quality of life with all the constraints of his condition. From that day, my mission became to help my father maintain healthy blood sugar levels and eliminate his lifestyle constraints, without any negative effects on his lifestyle.

I found the answer in Ayurveda; that’s how CuraLife was born. Since then, CuraLife has expanded its vision to improving the quality of life for everyone around the world. We do this by blending modernized ancient Ayurveda principles with modern-day science and technology and creating supportive communities for people on their journeys to health.

Join us on our mission to disrupt an industry and help millions of people lead higher quality lives.
settings.cmpncltr_desc: The CuraLife team is driven by one mission – improving the quality of life for people around the world. And we work incredibly hard to achieve that goal through life-changing products, easily digestible education, and thriving communities. We care deeply, think globally, and work tirelessly to create a happier, healthier world.

settings.cpwr_desc: Supports healthy pancreatic beta cells function
Promotes Short & Long Term Healthy & Balanced blood glucose levels
Reduces the craving for sugars & other carbs
Supports pancreas, liver, and kidney health

settings.wht_desc:
CuraLin is a 100% natural glucose support supplement for people looking to maintain healthy blood sugar levels and enjoy life's events to the fullest. It works by blending ancient Ayurveda practices with modern science and technology into a spectacular, synergistic glucose support formula.

Each CuraLin capsule is manufactured close to the source, using only premium ingredients. Secret production processes ensure that each capsule is highly potent and safe. All facilities are GMP & ISO 9001 certified, independent quality controls assures that you get only the safest, highest quality supplements possible.

CuraLin comprises of 9 natural ingredients. Scroll down to learn more about the formula.

settings.pwing_desc: Swertia Chirata is a beautiful purple flower containing active compounds that promote cellular glucose metabolism, support the release of insulin from the pancreas, and keep a healthy rate of glucose absorption in the digestive system.

Also known as Indian gooseberry or Emblica Officinalis, the active
                                                property
                                                in Amla is Tannoid, which helps support the physiological function of
                                                pancreatic cells.

Also known as Curcuma Longa, Turmeric has been used in Eastern medicinal
                                                systems for hundreds of years to help people maintain healthy glucose
                                                levels
                                                though healthy insulin tolerance.

Also known as Karela or Momordica Charantia, Bitter Melon is traditionally used in Eastern medicinal systems to promote healthy physiological function in pancreatic cells, supports glucose absorption, and the sensitivity of the muscle cells to insulin.

Cinnamon has many benefits, including supporting healthy glucose absorption & metabolism, promoting healthy insulin release, circulation & sensitivity, and maintaining healthy levels of gluconeogenesis. It also supports healthy weight loss, promotes healthy HbA1c and fasting blood sugar, healthy cholesterol levels, and promotes a healthy nervous system.

Also known as Trigonella Foenum Graecum, Fenugreek contains fibers that promotes insulin production, release & sensitivity. Fenugreek also helps support a healthy rate of carbohydrate absorption in the digestive system.

The active compounds in Pirorhiza Kurroa act as an anti-oxidant and promotes healthy liver function (protecting it from toxins). This supports healthy glucose tolerance and helps people maintain a healthy weight.

Also known as Eugenia Jambolana, the active components in Syzygium Cumini supports a healthy physiological function in the liver, creating a reservoir of glucose macromolecules, thereby helping maintain healthy fasting blood glucose levels.
Gymnema Sylvestre has many active compounds including Saponin, which is known to help manage cravings for carbohydrates. Metabolically, it promotes healthy insulin release.

settings.heading: What is
settings.article-banner-content:
Type 2 diabetes is a chronic condition that affects
the way the body metabolizes glucose.

settings.heading: This is your
settings.desc_left:
It’s a pathway for blood to flow through your body. Blood carries oxygen and nutrients to feed your body. These nutrients include glucose.
What is glucose?
Glucose is your body’s fuel.

Your body is constantly regulating the amount of glucose in your blood. That way, you always have the energy you need.
This incredible process is managed by insulin. Insulin kind of acts as a key to unlock the door of your cell so that it can remove glucose from your body. That's how insulin naturally cotrols your blood sugar levels.

For most people, this process is so seamless, they don’t even realize it’s happening.
settings.desc_right:
As we know all too well, there are times when something goes wrong. Perhaps the body isn’t producing enough insulin to offset sugar intake. Or the blood cells aren’t complying well with insulin’s orders. If this happens, glucose cannot exit the bloodstream.

Next thing you know, there’s a huge traffic jam of glucose in the bloodstream, one that keeps piling up.

With no way to use up the existing glucose, the glucose traffic jam grows, getting bigger and bigger. This build-up of glucose changes the blood from its normal ‘watery-like’ state into a thicker liquid. Something more like syrup. And if the amount of sugar in someone’s blood reaches a certain level, this person will be diagnosed as diabetic.

So, in a nutshell, diabetes is the body’s inability to process glucose.

settings.harmful-list-content: The thicker blood puts more pressure on the eye (intraocular eye pressure), which is why diabetes can lead to blurry vision or blindness.
Thick blood slows circulation, preventing the nervous system from getting enough blood. This can lead to nerve damage and neuropathy, a constant tingling or burning feeling in the limbs.
Not enough blood flow can starve outer limbs like the feet and legs. This can lead to complications ending with limb amputations.

Organs like the kidneys, liver, and pancreas need to work harder to filter all that sugar from the body. They can get overworked, leading to organ failure. Plaque begins to build up in the bloodstream, increasing the risk of a stroke.
Worst of all, this puts more pressure on your heart, increasing the risk of a heart attack.

settings.heading: Why is
settings.subheading2: When there is too much glucose in your blood, it becomes physically thicker. Similar to syrup.
settings.harmful-desc: Now, if your body is made to process blood, you can imagine how hard it would have to work to process something thick like syrup. This can cause some serious short-term and long-term health issues.

settings.symptoms-content: As glucose builds up in the body, your kidneys remove some of it through urine (your kidneys are trying to help your insulin get the job done), making you run for the bathroom more and more.
The lack of ready-to-use energy (your body can’t use its fuel) leads to constant tiredness and fatigue. No matter how many naps you might take.
All of that urination pulls fluids from your body, causing dehydration and an unquenchable thirst. You can drink liters and liters of water, and still be dehydrated.
A tingling or burning feeling in the hands and feet is caused by poor blood circulation and nerve damage. It’s like your foot is asleep and you just can't seem to wake it up.
Remember, your body uses glucose as fuel. If you aren’t getting fuel, your body will think it’s still hungry. Always. Hungry.
Breath that smells foul, like a strong nail polish, is caused by high levels of ketones - even if you’re downing Listerine like there’s no tomorrow.
The buildup of intraocular eye pressure can cause blurry vision or blindness, even if you’ve always had perfect sight.

settings.myths-content-left: Diabetes does not come from sugar. Diabetes develops when your body is no longer able to make or use insulin, so the sugar you consume cannot be converted into energy or fat. Diabetes is caused when the glucose just hangs around in the body.

While children with type 1 diabetes will always have symptoms, type 2 diabetes could easily go undiagnosed. There are over 7 MILLION undiagnosed diabetics in the USA alone. That’s why it’s important to get tested!
There is no known cure for diabetes, including insulin injections. Insulin shots simply give your body an extra dose of the hormone because it's unable to produce enough on its own.

Diabetes is not contagious.
Although diabetes is genetic and runs through some families, it cannot be caught like a cold or a flu.

settings.myths-heading-right: Insulin pills help you control diabetes
settings.myths-content-right: You can’t take insulin orally. Because insulin is a protein, if you took it as a pill, it would digest in your stomach and wouldn’t make it to the blood stream. There are other pills and capsules diabetics can take, but they do not include insulin.

settings.myths-heading-right:
If you have
diabetes, you
need to take medicines
settings.myths-content-right: Many diabetics are able to manage their condition with diet and lifestyle changes. There are also natural products to improve your glycemic response. More on that later.

settings.myths-heading-right:
If you have diabetes,
you need to eat
special foods
settings.myths-content-right: Most of the foods claiming to be healthy for people with diabetes also raise glucose levels and offer no benefit to diabetics. It’s officially recommended that diabetics eat a healthy diet that’s low in saturated fat.

settings.myths-heading-right: If you have diabetes, you can never eat chocolate or sweets
settings.myths-content-right: As part of an overall healthy diet and lifestyle, diabetics can eat chocolate or sweets in moderation.

settings.treatment-content-left:
Most diabetics take oral diabetes medications. Metformin is the most prescribed. It decreases the amount of glucose that you absorb from food and reduces the glucose produced by the liver. If the condition worsens, other oral drugs may be prescribed, including sulfonylureas, GLP1 agonists, DPP4 inhibitors, SGLT2 inhibitors, and others.

SIDE EFFECTS

  • • Diarrhea
  • • Pancreas failure
  • • Gas
  • • Infections
  • • Constipation
  • • Fungal growths
  • • Heart failure
  • • High cholesterol
  • • Headaches
  • • Vomiting

settings.treatment-content-right:
Insulin injections are used to control blood glucose levels that are too high to be controlled by oral medications alone. The insulin supplements what your body isn’t producing on its own. Unfortunately, insulin cannot be taken orally. Insulin users have to inject themselves at least twice a day (or more!) depending on their blood sugar levels. A big disadvantage of insulin injections: modern, more effective forms of insulin are becoming increasingly unaffordable. Some insulin users have even started rationing their insulin because they cannot afford the correct amount. Insulin costs have more than doubled in the last 5 years alone!

SIDE EFFECTS

  • • Redness
  • • Dizziness
  • • Swelling
  • • Blurred vision
  • • Itching
  • • Fast heartbeat
  • • Weight gain
  • • Sweating
  • • Constipation
  • • Weakness
  • • Wheezing
  • • Muscle cramps

settings.heading:
Are there natural ways to
maintain healthy glucose levels?
settings.description:
The most recommended ways of managing your diabetes are through nutrition and lifestyle changes.

Studies show that eating healthy, getting more exercise and movement into your day, and making other lifestyle adjustments can lower blood sugar.

Some diabetics even use their diagnosis as an opportunity to become the healthiest they’ve ever been!

settings.diet-heading: Snack on fresh fruits, vegetables, and nuts
settings.diet-content: Instead of candy, chips, and unhealthy snacks

settings.diet-heading: Drink water, unsweetened tea, and enjoy your coffee black.
settings.diet-content: Cut out soda, juice, and other sugary drinks

settings.diet-heading: Eat lean meats, poultry or fish
settings.diet-content: Avoid processed meats and cold cuts

settings.diet-heading: Go for leafy greens, sweet potato and low GI vegetable side dishes
settings.diet-content: Instead of starchy bread, pasta, rice, or white potatoes

settings.diet-heading: Limit alcohol intake and opt for red wine
settings.diet-content: Instead of beer, cocktails, or spirits

settings.heading:
WHAT
SHOULD I EAT?
settings.subheading: However, there are some good recommendations to get you started.
settings.description:
Your body is unique.
Different than anyone else’s.
There isn’t one universally recommended diabetes diet.
Some foods that spike some peoples’ blood sugar won’t
spike yours, and vice versa. You’ll need to experiment by eating
foods and checking your blood sugar two hours after meals
with a home glucometer to learn what works for you.
settings.heading-bottom: Don’t forget to enjoy yourself from time to time. It’s much easier to stick to an overall healthy diet when you allow yourself the occasional treat!
settings.content-bottom: Keep in mind, living healthy isn’t about removing things from your diet, but adding in healthy & nutritious foods that your body will love.

settings.tips-list-content: One that you will stick with.

settings.tips-list-heading: Try to add movement into your day.
settings.tips-list-content: Take the stairs instead of the elevator, or park your car farther from where you’re going and walk the rest of the way.
If your blood sugar swings easily from high to low, check your blood sugar before and after exercising and make sure to keep glucose tablets with you incase of a sugar low.

settings.heading:
MOVEMENT
& EXERCISE
settings.content:
All forms of exercise are good for people with diabetes. Exercising can lower your blood sugar, improve your heart health, reduce stress, and give you more energy.
You just need to get up and move!

Some fun physical activities are walking, hiking, cycling, weight training, yoga, stretching, and even gardening!

Another reason to exercise regularly is that it reduces weight. Weight loss is one of the best ways that you can reduce your blood sugar over the long run. Even a small amount of weight loss can really lower your blood sugar levels.

settings.lifestyle-list-content: Looking at the brighter side of things can help cheer up any day. Finding humor and love in your day to day life will release positivity hormones, lower stress, and lower blood sugar levels.
If you’re a smoker, make the diagnosis the reason you needed to quit. Going smoke-free helps your insulin sensitivity, lowering your blood sugar.
Losing even just a few pounds can really improve the way your body processes glucose. And, in addition to that, weight loss will just make you feel (and look) better overall!
Learn about diabetes. Understand the symptoms. Knowing that you should check your feet a few times a week can be the difference between letting cuts get infected and avoiding infections altogether.

If you don’t have many diabetic friends, meeting some will help you support each other on your journeys to health. You should join an online diabetes community like ‘Winning Type 2 Diabetes Together’ on Facebook. That's where thousands of diabetics support each other and answer each other’s questions 24/7. ‘Winning Type 2 Diabetes Together’ offers free membership to type 2 diabetics, so just search for the group on Facebook and join.

There are many Ayurvedic dietary supplements that can support the healthy function of the pancreas, liver and spleen. There are also specialty supplements formulated specifically for people with diabetes. They promote healthy blood sugar levels through supporting insulin sensitivity, glucose metabolism, and insulin release.

settings.heading: LIFESTYLE CHANGES
settings.content: Many diabetics use their disease to become the happiest and healthiest they have ever been. Here are some tips for doing that yourself.

settings.comp-list-content:
• Reduces cravings for sugar & carbs
  • Encourages healthy insulin release
  • Promotes a healthy rate of carb absorption

• Promotes stable blood glucose levels
  • Enhances general cognition
  • Helps the pancreas function well
  • Supports vitality and graceful aging

• Supports healthy insulin sensitivity
  • Promotes a strong immune system
  • Maintains balanced glucose levels

• Promotes healthy fasting glucose levels through a reservoir of glucose macromolecules
  • Supports healthy liver function

• Promotes insulin sensitivity
  • Supports cellular glucose absorption
  • Promotes healthy physiological function in damaged pancreatic cells

• Contains lots of fiber
  • Promotes insulin production, secretion, and sensitivity
  • Supports a healthy rate of carbohydrate absorption
• Supports the healthy release of insulin from the pancreas, glucose absorption from the digestive system, and intracellular metabolism of glucose

• Promotes cellular glucose metabolism
  • Helps maintain balanced glucose levels

• Contains powerful antioxidants
  • Supports the healthy transformation of starch into glucose subunits and the absorption speed of carbohydrates in the body

• Packed with antioxidants
  • Promotes liver and spleen health
  • Supports glucose tolerance
  • Helps support a healthy weight

settings.heading: Learn about
settings.content:
The Ayurveda medical system is very complex. Simply put, it aims to balance the digestive system, endocrine system, and body movement systems (circulatory, respiratory, muscular, and nervous).

Ayurvedic formulas use herbal recipes to create a holistic balance inside the body so you can maintain optimal health, even as a diabetic.

The added support Ayurvedic diabetes supplements gives to your daily nutrition help can be powerful enough to drastically improve your lifestyle and enjoyment as a diabetic.
settings.compound-heading:
Which Diabetes Compounds
Are Used in Ayurveda?

settings.next-content-left:
My doctor said I’m diabetic.

diabetes has on my sex life?

everyone around me?

beer or wine again?

settings.heading: Your Next

settings.bottom-content:
We put together an educational newsletter that will explain all this over the course of a few days.

Enter your email address to get all the most important information for understanding how to enjoy life with diabetes.
